questions.explanation: Energy signals have finite total energy E = ∫|x(t)|²dt < ∞. They 'run out' eventually. Examples include pulses and decaying exponentials that don't extend forever.
Sinusoids extend infinitely in time, giving infinite total energy. But their average power P = A²/2 is finite. Infinite energy + finite power = power signal.
For a sinusoid x(t) = Acos(ωt), average power P = A²/2. Here A = 6, so P = 36/2 = 18. This is a fundamental formula to memorize.

questions.prompt: If a signal has finite energy, its average power is:
questions.explanation: Finite energy spread over infinite time gives zero average power: P = lim(E/T) as T→∞ = 0. This is why energy and power signals are mutually exclusive.

questions.prompt: The formula for signal energy is:
questions.explanation: Energy E = ∫|x(t)|²dt over all time. We use magnitude squared to handle complex signals and ensure non-negative energy. Not just x(t), not time-averaged.

questions.prompt: A rectangular pulse of amplitude A and width 2T has energy:
questions.explanation: E = ∫|x(t)|²dt = ∫A²dt from -T to T = A² × 2T = 2A²T. Area under the squared amplitude for the pulse duration.

questions.prompt: A DC signal x(t) = 5 has power:
questions.explanation: For a constant signal x(t) = A, power P = A². No division by 2 like sinusoids because the signal is constant, not oscillating. P = 5² = 25.

questions.prompt: Can a signal be both energy and power type?
questions.explanation: Energy and power classifications are mutually exclusive. If E is finite, P = 0 (energy signal). If P is finite, E = ∞ (power signal). No signal can be both.
The decaying exponential has E = ∫e^(-2t)dt from 0 to ∞ = 1/2, which is finite. Finite energy means it's an energy signal, not a power signal.

questions.prompt: Why use |x(t)|² instead of x(t)² in energy formulas?
questions.explanation: For complex-valued signals, |x|² = x × x* ensures the result is always real and non-negative. For real signals, |x|² = x², so it reduces to the same thing.
